newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends down on weak sentiment.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends down on weak sentiment.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended down on Tuesday with selling from big copper producers weakening market sentiment, traders said.
The most actively traded September 1997 contract ended at 23,780 yuan ($2,868) per tonne, losing 110 yuan. It opened at an intraday high of 23,850 and hit a low of 23,730 yuan per tonne.
June fell 70 yuan to 23,380, July 90 to 23,540, August 120 to 23,680 and October 100 to 23,800.
Combined volume fell to 34,700 tonnes from 46,440 tonnes.
Copper opened slightly lower and fell further for most of the session.
Traders said investors were unwilling to buy due to a lack of news in favour of long position holders, but lower physical copper prices encouraged selling by big producers.
They said investors could not see any upward momentum and so prefered to stay on the sidelines. This led to the fall in trading volume.
"Retail investors dominated today's trade," a trader said.
The price of physical copper is around 23,300 yuan in the Shanghai area, traders said.
Any show of strength on the London Metal Exchange (LME) would help boost local interest in buying, traders said.
But they said they expected to see copper producers build short positions at the key resistance level of 24,000 yuan.
A small stock drawdown of 475 tonnes on the LME on Tuesday saw the red metal soften in early trade below $2,470, with support seen around $2,440-$2450 per tonne.
Shanghai trade sources said local copper should move in a range of 23,500-24,000 yuan per tonne in the next few days.
Aluminium ended down. June fell 60 yuan to 15,450, July 210 to 15,600, August 50 to 15,800, and September 150 to 15,950.
Combined volume rose to 1,890 tonnes from 1,280 tonnes.
